entry.title: Is Your Traceability Strategy Ready for 2027? Discover SAP Corporate Serialization
entry.content:
Product traceability is no longer just a regulatory requirement; it has become a strategic imperative. Today, it underpins risk management, accelerates recalls, and builds consumer trust in increasingly complex supply chains. A robust traceability strategy safeguards brand integrity and drives competitive advantage in a market that demands transparency.

Historically, industries relied on SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure (AII) and SAP Object Event Repository (OER) on the NetWeaver platform as the standard for traceability, turning compliance into operational efficiency. But with SAP ending mainstream maintenance for NetWeaver applications by 2027, forward-thinking companies must plan their next move.

The strategic path forward is migration to SAP Corporate Serialization. More than an upgrade, it’s a transformative step that unifies AII and OER capabilities into a modern, integrated platform designed for today’s global supply chains. This transition future-proofs operations, meets evolving transparency requirements, and positions businesses for sustainable growth.

This article will guide supply chain leaders through this critical shift, addressing the most pressing questions about SAP Corporate Serialization:

  • What is SAP Corporate Serialization?
  • What capabilities does SAP Corporate Serialization offer?
  • What are the use cases of SAP Corporate Serialization?
  • What is the business value of SAP Corporate Serialization?

 

What is SAP Corporate Serialization?

SAP Corporate Serialization is a secure, private cloud-based SaaS solution that layers seamlessly on top of existing SAP ERP systems, consolidating the capabilities of SAP AII and SAP OER into a single, cohesive platform. It provides scalable serialization management, integrating with shop-floor systems and meeting global regulatory requirements.

The solution enables end-to-end visibility across the entire product lifecycle; from subcomponents to finished goods; transforming traceability from static records into a dynamic narrative. It authenticates products, combats counterfeiting, and manages both batch and logistics unit distribution. By unifying serialized data and events across suppliers, manufacturing sites, and customers, and integrating with systems like ERP, WMS, MES, and RFID/barcode technologies, SAP Corporate Serialization captures every event from production to delivery (Figure 1)

Figure 1:- System Landscape with SAP Corporate Serialization

 

What capabilities does SAP Corporate Serialization offer?

1. Central Serial Number Management: Generate flexible alphanumeric, randomized, or product-specific serials and distribute them in bulk, reducing manual effort, ensuring accuracy, and supporting compliance.

2. End-to-End Integration and Extensibility: Connect seamlessly with SAP Business Network, SAP EWM, SAP ECC/S/4HANA, and non-SAP systems (Figure 2), while also extending the solution to accommodate customer-specific requirements and traceability attributes; enhancing operational decision-making and supply chain visibility.

Figure 2: SAP Corporate Serialization Integration Options

3. Automation and Standardization: Automate serialization, reporting, and data exchange; streamlining workflows, enforcing consistent processes, and lowering risk of errors.

4. User Experience and Interfaces Monitoring: Intuitive SAP GUI and FIORI interfaces combined with SAP Application Interface Framework (AIF) monitoring; enabling faster onboarding, real-time transaction oversight, and quick resolution of exceptions.

5. Future-Proof, Cost-Efficient Architecture: Supports GS1, EPCIS, and other formats like IMEI, UID, and UDI. Consolidates legacy AII and OER systems, minimizes customization, and aligns with SAP S/4HANA and industry standards; reducing total cost of ownership while preparing businesses for evolving regulatory and operational demands.

 

What are the use cases of SAP Corporate Serialization?

SAP Corporate Serialization delivers flexible, industry-specific solutions that transform traceability from a compliance requirement into a strategic advantage. In automotive, it tracks EV batteries and safety-critical components throughout production and service lifecycles. Aerospace and defense benefit from full traceability of iUID-marked parts to meet stringent regulatory standards.

Consumer products leverage the platform to authenticate goods, combat counterfeiting, and engage buyers through digital product passports, while managing reusable assets like beverage kegs. In consumer electronics, it ensures serialization of devices, components, and software licenses, supporting traceability, warranty tracking, and fraud prevention. Tobacco and beverage industries use SAP Corporate Serialization to manage serial numbers linked to tax stamps and track premium or returnable products; ensuring compliance, authenticity, and streamlined reuse.

The hi-tech, utilities, and specialty gas sectors gain precise tracking of high-value components, spare parts, and cylinders, improving asset visibility, safety, and operational efficiency. In agribusiness, each pallet or shipment is tagged with a unique serial number, capturing its journey from harvest to delivery; enhancing logistics, inventory accuracy, and supply chain transparency.

Healthcare and medical device companies benefit from UDI compliance and post-sale serialization, linking components to digital service records to optimize lifecycle management, anticipate maintenance, and strengthen customer trust.

Across all these sectors, SAP Corporate Serialization proves its scalability and adaptability, supporting both compliance-driven and value-driven business outcomes, while turning traceability into a driver of efficiency, trust, and growth.

 

What is the business value of SAP Corporate Serialization?

Transitioning to SAP Corporate Serialization is not just about staying supported beyond 2027; it’s a strategic move that transforms traceability into a driver of efficiency, visibility, and growth. The platform operates in the background like an autopilot, automating serial number management operations, which improving employee productivity and freeing QA, logistics, and customer service teams to focus on exceptions, while providing instant access to service histories.

By centralizing serialized data, it reduces compliance and risk management costs, streamlines QA and RA workflows, and provides fully traceable records for audits. During recalls, affected products or components are identified quickly and precisely, minimizing operational disruption and waste.

Beyond operational gains, SAP Corporate Serialization safeguards brand reputation and drives sales. End-to-end traceability ensures authenticity, combats counterfeiting, and builds consumer trust, while digital experiences like product passports enhance engagement and encourage repeat purchases; protecting both brand and revenue.

Conclusion

The adoption of SAP Corporate Serialization is far more than a system upgrade; it’s a strategic investment in resilience, transparency, and long-term competitiveness. As the 2027 deadline approaches, the companies that act now will not only secure compliance but also unlock new value through lower costs, greater agility, and stronger consumer trust.

The question is no longer if serialization will redefine your supply chain, but how fast you can position your business to lead. Our team stands ready to partner with you; bringing best practices and proven expertise to ensure a seamless transition and help you capture the full potential of an intelligent product traceability ecosystem.

Learn how leading companies leverage SAP Corporate Serialization to achieve end-to-end product traceability, reduce operational complexity, and drive business resilience.

entry.title: Intelligent Supply Chains in Action: Fujitsu’s Agentic AI Approach to Global Trade Challenges
entry.content:
Introduction

Across industries, supply chain disruptions have become the new normal. Global manufacturers are navigating a complex web of challenges, including shifting trade policies, volatile energy prices, climate-driven events, and the growing demand for sustainable operations. The systems and strategies that once brought stability now struggle to keep up with this constant change.

According to a 2024 report by Maersk, 76% of respondents reported experiencing supply chain disruptions, and a startling 58% of them reported that the costs exceeded their predictions. From sudden tariff changes that reshape sourcing decisions to unexpected raw material shortages or port closures, disruptions no longer come one at a time as they overlap, compound, and evolve faster than traditional planning tools can respond.

In this environment, organisations need more than data visibility. They need decision intelligence systems that can sense change, learn continuously, and act responsibly in real time. This cannot be achieved in isolation, and an ecosystem or network play is a must. This is also where the latest innovations in Artificial Intelligence, like Agentic AI, can help redefine supply chain resilience.

The role of Agentic AI in Supply Chain Resilience

Agentic AI has the potential to power the next evolution of intelligent supply chain management. Instead of waiting for analysts or planners to interpret data, AI agents can continuously monitor supply, logistics, and market signals and then autonomously simulate and recommend the best response.

A few scenarios include:

  • Sudden geopolitical tensions? AI agents instantly recalculate costs, identify alternate suppliers, and propose optimised procurement mixes.
  • An energy-price surge? AI agents can suggest shifting production to lower-cost facilities or off-peak hours to protect margins and emissions goals.

SAP and its partner ecosystem are harnessing the power of Agentic AI to bring the vision of an intelligent supply chain to life. As a strategic SAP partner, Fujitsu is at the forefront of this innovation - creating next-generation solutions that enhance visibility, resilience, and responsiveness across global value networks.

Among the many factors disrupting supply chains today, cross-border tariffs remain one of the most complex and persistent challenges. In this article, we explore how Fujitsu’s Agentic AI-driven offerings are designed to help businesses anticipate, adapt to, and overcome these disruptions - enabling a smarter, more connected, and future-ready supply chain.

Building a Resilient Supply Chain to respond to Trade disruptions

In recent months, global trade dynamics have become increasingly unpredictable. The rules that once made it easy for goods to flow across borders - like free trade agreements - are now being challenged by new tariffs, shifting political alliances, and unexpected disruptions across the trade lanes. In a recent study published by BCG in 2025, it is estimated that at least 20% to 30% of EBIT margins for companies across all manufacturing sectors are at risk from higher tariffs!

Real-World Example: How Agentic AI Transformed a Global Electronics Manufacturer

A leading global electronics manufacturer in Asia faced significant challenges stemming from supply chain uncertainties, siloed enterprise systems and fragmented data. Their complex IT landscape made it difficult to access and interpret critical information across departments, slowing down decision-making during high-stakes disruptions.

Traditional point-to-point data integration approaches would have taken years to unify these disparate systems. Instead, the company sought a transformative solution - one that could consolidate enterprise data, enrich it with industry and business context, and dramatically accelerate decision cycles.

Agentic AI proved pivotal in transforming the company’s response to disruptions.

During disruptions such as trade tariffs or natural disasters like earthquakes, the manufacturer needed to rapidly assess the impact across their supply chain. This required synthesising internal enterprise data with external sources such as demographic trends, trade data, and harmonised system (HS) codes to simulate scenarios and take informed action.

As part of a broader digital transformation initiative, the company explored how Agentic AI could address supply chain shortages. By deploying intelligent agents across multiple systems - procurement, sales, inventory, and orchestration - they enabled real-time data access and contextual decision-making. These agents were trained to perform specialised tasks and provide actionable recommendations to business users.

For example, in the case of a raw material shortage, agents could evaluate multiple alternatives:

  • Sourcing from an alternative supplier,
  • Adjusting production schedules based on material availability, or
  • Engaging with customers to reschedule orders while maintaining service levels.

Each scenario required granular simulation across millions of SKUs, factoring in product, customer, and supplier contexts. The orchestrator agent played a pivotal role by assessing each option through the lens of cost, priority, and service level, ultimately recommending the most optimal path forward.

This innovative use of Agentic AI not only enhanced agility and collaboration across the enterprise but also earned a global recognition. The World Economic Forum’s AI Governance Alliance acknowledged this solution as one of 18 advanced AI applications transforming business worldwide.

Turning Data into Decisions

Expanding data visibility across enterprise, market, and regulatory sources enhances predictive accuracy and resilience.

Some other examples of how companies can use data and smart technologies to solve supply chain challenges encountered in tariff change scenarios are as follows:

  • Profit and Cost Analysis: By mapping out where costs are rising due to tariffs, companies can decide whether to pass those costs on to customers, absorb them, or find cheaper alternatives.
  • Pricing Simulations: Businesses can test how different prices will affect demand and profits in different tariff scenarios, helping them find the best balance between staying competitive and making money.
  • Operational Changes: If a key supplier is hit by a new tariff, companies can quickly see what other options are available, compare costs and quality, and make a switch if needed.

Fujitsu’s Multi-AI Orchestration Platform

Fujitsu has developed a Multi-AI agent orchestration platform for use cases such as Profit Margin & Cost Analysis that can leverage data stored in both SAP and non-SAP systems to present specific scenarios that can impact a customer’s supply chain. Using the simulation capabilities of this offering, multiple scenarios can be developed and compared, and the right strategy can be devised. The agentic AI platform leverages the data and helps to implement the decisions back into SAP applications like SAP S/4HANA SAP Integrated Business Planning and SAP Digital Manufacturing to effectuate the optimal plan chosen earlier. In the future, these agents could be extended to support SAP Business Network Supply Chain Collaboration and Supply Chain Orchestration as well.

These offerings are also complementary to the AI innovations delivered by SAP with the Business Suite e.g. seamless access with Joule, enhanced collaboration and decision making with SCM agents, etc.

Preparing for an AI-Enabled Future

Introducing technological capabilities isn’t enough. Companies also need to change the way they work with AI. This includes:

  • Cultivating an “AI-first” mindset: AI projects executed with a traditional mindset rarely deliver transformative outcomes. A transformational mindset is required to transform supply chains with AI. A few key aspects are as follows:
    • Myths like “AI will completely replace humans” are making way to “AI agents will work alongside humans”. But accepting this at an individual level requires humans to trust AI.
    • Especially within the supply chain, one cannot afford to have unreliable supply chain plans or manufacturing schedules. Balancing the level of AI autonomy with human empowerment is key to gaining this trust.
    • An AI-first and transformational mindset is required in transforming supply chains with AI
  • AI upskilling: Technologies such as Generative AI are being widely used by people to simplify their personal tasks. However, when it comes to corporate use of such tools, there are several nuances that we need to be aware of, like trusted tools, enterprise context and security concerns. These also apply specifically to the use of AI in supply chains
  • Improve Network relationships: A supply chain network includes partners like component suppliers, logistics partners etc. These partners are important to ensure optimal running of the supply chain in normal times and become critical during disruptions. Trusted data sharing, clear communication channels, and robust digital capabilities are critical to sustaining a resilient partner ecosystem

Conclusion

Agentic AI is redefining how organisations anticipate, adapt, and act amid global supply chain volatility. Fujitsu and SAP’s joint innovation demonstrates that the future of supply chain resilience lies not just in data, but in intelligent, autonomous collaboration.

Learn More

If you’d like to see how such technology can be turned into a solution in action or to learn more, consider attending the Fujitsu ActivateNow event in Singapore.

entry.title: Release Highlights of advanced Available-To-Promise (aATP) in SAP Cloud ERP, Private Edition 2025
entry.content:
Order Promising plays a pivotal role in connecting supply chain planning—driven by SAP Integrated Business Planning—with execution in SAP Cloud ERP, across the order-to-cash process. Advanced ATP (aATP) in SAP ERP Private Cloud remains the flagship solution, delivering real-time, constraint-based order confirmations that enhance supply chain performance and ensure reliable customer commitments.

Figure 1 : Key functionalities of advanced ATP

With the 2025 FPS0 release, SAP has addressed several highly requested customer requirements for advanced ATP. Key enhancements in this release include consolidation of shipping locations during Alternative-Based Confirmation, package size consideration in availability checks, greater flexibility for manual confirmation adjustments, length-based ATP for the cable industry, and characteristics evaluation during availability checks—delivering critical capabilities to support complex business needs.

Let’s do a deep dive into some of the key capabilities.

Consolidation of Shipping Locations

When customers order products available in partial quantities across multiple distribution centers or stock-holding locations, Alternative-Based Confirmation(ABC) now enables consolidation into a single location through automated creation of internal stock transport orders, ensuring one streamlined shipment instead of multiple ones.

Figure 2: Distributed fulfilment with Alternative-Based Confirmation (ABC)

Figure 3: Consolidated fulfilment with ABC with automated creation of Stock Transport Orders (STO)

This is especially valuable in export processes, where goods must be consolidated at the most suitable location for tariff, tax declaration, or letter-of-credit handling. The process reduces manual effort in creating stock transport documents, improves delivery date accuracy, and enhances compliance with export regulations. By optimizing logistics, it minimizes complexity, enhances customer satisfaction, and ensures efficient, legally compliant global shipping operations.

You can enable the automated creation of STOs during the process of Alternative Based Confirmation in ABC strategy.

Figure 4 – Alternative-Based Confirmation with Stock Transport Document Creation

Unrestricted checks in Interactive Backorder Processing

Interactive Backorder Processing (IBOP) enables order fulfillment managers to adjust confirmations in real time based on business priorities. During unplanned supply shortages, scheduled Backorder Processing runs may be too late to resolve issues. IBOP provides flexibility to manually redistribute or modify confirmations for selected requirements, ensuring critical demands are met. The tool offers contextual information to support informed decision-making. Order fulfillment managers can also override constraints such as Product Allocation and Supply Protection in exceptional cases, addressing escalated business needs. This capability is invaluable during supply chain disruptions, empowering managers to respond quickly, reduce delays, and maintain customer satisfaction. 

Figure 5 – Interactive Backorder Processing with Unrestricted checks

Order confirmation based on packaging size

Many businesses sell products in predefined package sizes, such as cartons of 24 cans or boxes of 20 packs. The enhanced availability check feature helps align orders with these packaging rules by automatically rounding requested quantities to the nearest valid unit, like full pallets, pallet layers, or cases, based on set rounding profiles, and rounding down confirmed quantities to meet packaging and transportation constraints. Business Add-In can also be used to incorporate custom rounding logic.

Figure 6 – Rounding in aATP

This approach makes order quantities realistic from the start, reducing the need for manual corrections or late changes. The result is improved process efficiency, smoother execution, fewer errors, and enhanced customer satisfaction through reliable and accurate deliveries.

Characteristics evaluation in Supply creation-Based Confirmation

Supply creation-Based Confirmation (SBC) integrates aATP with PP/DS to confirm sales orders by triggering production when supply is insufficient, considering both finite capacity and component availability. The latest release also incorporates CDP characteristics during confirmation—crucial for mill industries that plan, and produce based on product attributes and rely on block planning over production resources.

Length based availability check

Cable industries often sell products based on length, making precise availability checks critical. The length based-availability check in Supply creation-Based Confirmation (SBC) ensures that a single coil contains the required minimum length to meet an order. For example, if a customer needs a 1000m steel cable, the system only confirms it if a coil of at least 1000m is available—smaller coils adding up to 1000m cannot be used. Once validated, ATP can trigger a cutting order, or in case of shortages, initiate production. This capability helps industries match customer requirements exactly, avoid unusable inventory, integrate tightly with production, and ensure reliable delivery commitments.

Figure 7: Length based ATP with Supply creation-Based Confirmation

That’s not all. Supply Protection has been enhanced to resolve overprotection and other critical issues causing unexpected results in sales order confirmations. New rating attributes in Alternative-Based Confirmation are added to simplify the maintenance of supersession chains. Enhanced Business Add-Ins provide greater flexibility to meet custom requirements—allowing modification of substitution results in ABC, insertion or manipulation of requirements, and advanced sorting in Backorder Processing, etc.

These are just a few highlights from the wide range of new enhancements in Order Promising in SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition. With a strong roadmap focused on AI and Analytics, future releases will continue to deliver next-generation capabilities to meet evolving customer needs.

For more information on advanced ATP in SAP Cloud ERP, Private Edition, please get in touch with Sujeet Acharya (sujeet.acharya@sap.com) and Wolfram Schick (wolfram.schick@sap.com)

entry.title: Building Sustainable Supply Chains: From Design to Reuse
entry.content:
Building Sustainable Supply Chains: From Design to Reuse

Sustainability is no longer just a nice-to-have; it’s a business must. Customers, regulators, and investors expect companies to take responsibility not only for their own operations but also for the environmental and social impact across their entire supply chain. That’s where the concept of double materiality comes in: it examines both how sustainability risks and opportunities affect a company's financial performance and how its activities impact society and the environment.

The challenge? Supply chains are sprawling, multi-tiered networks that cross industries, continents, and regulatory systems. But within this complexity lies opportunity. With the right strategy, processes, and technology, companies can build supply chains that are not only resilient and compliant but also drivers of long-term value.

In this blog, we’ll explore how organizations can move step by step—from design to reuse—towards building truly sustainable supply chains, and we’ll highlight some of the SAP solutions that make this transformation possible.

Why Sustainable Supply Chains Matter

Supply chains are at the heart of the sustainability challenge. In industries such as automotive, consumer goods, and manufacturing, they can account for the majority of a company’s carbon footprint. Scope 3 emissions, encompassing those from suppliers, logistics, and product use, can account for more than 70% of a company's total greenhouse gas (GHG) impact.

And carbon is just one piece of the puzzle. Companies must also navigate regulatory requirements, such as EUDR and CBAM, improve resource efficiency, reduce waste, and prepare for climate-related risks, including water shortages and flooding. It sounds daunting, but within this complexity lies a real opportunity.

Think of the supply chain as a circle rather than a straight line:

  • Design sets the stage. Choices about materials, packaging, and product life cycles determine environmental impact long before anything is produced.
  • Plan and Procure shape how responsibly resources are sourced and how suppliers are engaged in meeting sustainability goals.
  • Manufacture is about efficiency and using less energy and water, generating less waste, and embedding circular practices into production.
  • Delivery focuses on logistics: reducing emissions in transportation, optimizing routes, and rethinking packaging.
  • The product usage shifts the spotlight to the customer, where durability, repairability, and energy efficiency influence both sustainability and satisfaction.
  • Reuse closes the loop through recycling, remanufacturing, or creating entirely new business models around product-as-a-service.

 

This circular approach transforms sustainability from a compliance exercise into a growth engine. Companies that weave sustainability into every step of their supply chain can cut costs, win customer trust, unlock new markets, and build resilience against disruptions.

Smart Design, Lower Impact

Take the example of a car seat. Sustainability starts in the design phase: the choice of materials, say eco-friendly upholstery instead of leather, has an immediate impact on the product’s footprint. In fact, leather use can trigger regulatory requirements in certain markets, such as the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) compliance in Europe. Beyond materials, the way the seat is designed also matters. A seat that’s easy to disassemble makes it simpler to recycle components or reuse some material later, extending its lifecycle.

This is where technology comes in. SAP Responsible Design and Production helps manufacturers anticipate future Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) fees, giving them the insight to make smarter design and packaging decisions upfront. Meanwhile, SAP Green Token offers chain-of-custody transparency for certified sustainable and recycled materials, providing the credibility companies need to back sustainability claims, including compliance with regulations like EUDR.

In addition, with SAP Product and REACH Compliance, manufacturers can assess and document the environmental compatibility and regional marketability of their products.

From Cost to Carbon: Why Supply Chain Planning Needs a Sustainability Upgrade

Supply chain planning has traditionally focused on three things: cost, availability, and quality. But today, there’s a new non-negotiable: sustainability. Take the former example of a car seat: if the design calls for leather, then in Europe that leather must be EUDR-certified. Certifications like this shouldn’t be seen as an afterthought; they need to carry the same weight in planning as cost or quality.

And it goes beyond compliance. In the past, planners compared scenarios to find the best margins or service levels. Now, the question is just as much about impact: Which scenario delivers the lowest carbon footprint?

Smarter planning naturally leads to less waste. Optimizing inventory and capacity not only improves efficiency and saves money, but it also reduces emissions, creating better outcomes for both the business and the planet.

For global manufacturers, this matters even more. Europe requires EUDR-certified leather, while other markets may not. By weaving sustainability into planning, companies can stay compliant in every region without sacrificing efficiency.

This is where solutions like SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) make a difference. IBP allows companies to embed sustainability into every step in the process, treating certifications as sustainability attributes, simulating emissions across scenarios, and flagging ESG risks before they escalate.

The bottom line: Future-proof supply chains don’t just balance cost and service; they balance cost, service, compliance, and environmental impact.

Procurement as a Catalyst for Sustainability

Procurement isn’t just about negotiating the best price or ensuring materials arrive on time; it's also about managing risk and optimizing supply chain efficiency. Every buying decision has a ripple effect on a company’s sustainability footprint, making procurement one of the most powerful levers for driving meaningful change.

Suppliers are validated based on their overall risk profile. This does include their exposure to climate change-related risks, their mitigation strategies, certifications, and overall sustainability performance. In our example of EUDR-certified leather, it is about the validation that the leather has not been produced by farms with deforestation practices. In addition, suppliers are requested to share the carbon footprint of their products, the calculation method, and potentially assurance documents. The capability of exchanging sustainability data, such as scope 3 emission data, across the value chain becomes crucial for collaboration to hit greenhouse targets. Analyzing the carbon footprint of different material choices allows companies to make informed sourcing decisions and balance cost, quality, and sustainability.

SAP offers multiple solutions to help customers. Embedding sustainability attributes into the risk assessment using SAP Ariba Supplier Risk helps to manage climate-related risks. Using SAP Sustainability Data Exchange supports a standardized and certified way to exchange sustainability data, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management calculates and analyzes emissions tied to product purchases, transportation, and manufacturing, and finally, SAP Green Token helps companies to be compliant with EUDR regulations.

When procurement leaders embrace these tools and practices, they move from simply buying materials to actively driving decarbonization and ensuring compliance. Sustainable buying isn’t a “nice to have” anymore; it’s a game-changer for business and the planet.

Beyond Compliance: Embedding Sustainability Into Manufacturing Operations

Once raw materials arrive at the factory floor, the responsibility shifts from sourcing to production. At this stage, manufacturers face a critical challenge: how to minimize energy use, conserve water, cut waste, ensure worker safety, and stay compliant with evolving regulations.

Sustainable manufacturing isn’t just about checking boxes; it’s about embedding smarter processes that strengthen resilience and competitiveness. Here’s how leading companies are approaching it:

  • Energy and emissions tracking: By modeling energy flows across production lines, manufacturers can allocate emissions directly to activities and products, providing the transparency required to develop and track decarbonization strategies.

  • Waste reduction: Cradle-to-grave waste management and recycling programs help eliminate inefficiencies and reduce environmental impact.

  • Worker health and safety: Predictive tools highlight potential hazards, while real-time tracking improves visibility into incidents and ensures safer working conditions.

Take upholstery manufacturing as an example. By modeling the energy flow of a production line, businesses can calculate the carbon footprint of each unit produced. This not only enables accurate product-level sustainability reporting but also highlights where efficiency gains can be made.

To enable this shift, technology plays a vital role. SAP solutions help manufacturers close the loop:

  • #SAP Environment Management monitors emissions, waste, and compliance across operations

  • #SAP Workplace Safety strengthens incident visibility and fosters a culture of safety

  • SAP Sustainability Footprint Management  calculates product footprints based on measured data for transparent reporting

When done right, sustainable manufacturing reduces risk, ensures compliance, and delivers products with smaller footprints, turning sustainability into a competitive advantage.

Sustainable Logistics: Reducing Emissions Beyond the Factory Gate

Once a product leaves the factory, its journey has only just begun. Trucks, ships, and planes carry it across regions and continents, but these movements come at a cost. The logistics and distribution phase is one of the biggest contributors to supply chain emissions. The good news? Smarter delivery models are proving that it’s possible to move goods efficiently while shrinking environmental impact. 

It starts with transportation optimization. By consolidating shipments, reducing empty miles, and adopting low-carbon fuels, companies can cut unnecessary emissions while saving costs.  Just as important is knowing how much carbon is being released. By tracking emissions from different types of transport and sharing that information with customers, companies can be more transparent, helping customers to make better, more eco-friendly decisions. 

Collaboration plays a powerful role, too. By sharing carbon footprint data with customers and partners, manufacturers can build trust and enable joint action. For example, the automotive supplier calculates the full carbon footprint of the car seats from the material used, the inbound transport of those materials, through manufacturing energy use, to outbound delivery. The results are shared with OEM partners via Catena-X, creating a shared foundation for decarbonization across the value chain.

Technology is what makes these advances scalable:

  • SAP Transportation Management optimizes routing and freight networks, reducing both emissions and costs.

  • SAP Sustainability Footprint Management calculates carbon emissions, including scope 3.1 as well as logistics-based emissions such as scope 3.4 and 3.9 categories.

  • SAP Sustainability Data Exchange enables transparent and secure sharing of carbon data across networks

By embedding sustainability into logistics, companies can reduce costs, meet rising customer expectations, and support Scope 3 reporting, all while ensuring their products reach the right place at the right time with a lighter footprint.

Closing the Loop: How Circular Supply Chains Create New Value

The final stage of a product’s life cycle isn’t really the end; it’s the beginning of a new cycle. That’s the power of circular supply chains: they extend product life, recover valuable resources, and dramatically cut waste. It starts with managing and auditing waste streams responsibly, making sure even hazardous materials are handled the right way. From there, recycled inputs can be looped back into production, reducing the need for virgin resources and shrinking the footprint of every product made. Partnerships with recyclers and waste handlers play a big role too, creating steady, sustainable flows of materials that companies can depend on. But one of the most powerful strategies is remanufacturing and reuse. By reusing components and remanufacturing products closer to home, companies recover higher value while cutting both costs and emissions tied to sourcing and logistics. This approach strengthens ties with suppliers and gives both providers and customers a chance to reduce waste and build more sustainable products together. In our example, car seat fabrics might not just be made from recycled plastics supplied by disposal companies, but also combined with cork-based materials to meet demand, lowering reliance on new resources while delivering products that customers want. SAP helps bring these strategies to life.  SAP Environment, Health, and Safety Management ensures compliance and auditing of waste streams, SAP Integrated Business Planning balances demand and supply for recycled inputs, and SAP Waste and Recycling makes it easier to collaborate with recyclers and waste handlers. The impact speaks for itself: car seat manufacturers, adopting circular supply chain practices, have cut carbon emissions by 52% through smarter routing and sustainable materials, reduced per-seat emissions by 34%, and made emissions reporting 75 times faster. Circular supply chains don’t just close the loop; they create new opportunities for efficiency, savings, and competitive advantage. The final stage is not the end but the beginning of a new cycle. Circular supply chains extend product life, recover resources, and reduce waste.

Conclusion: The Future of Supply Chains Is Sustainable, Digital, and Circular

Sustainable supply chains are no longer a niche initiative. They are central to regulatory compliance, market differentiation, and long-term resilience. By embedding sustainability from design to reuse, organizations can cut carbon emissions and waste, ensure compliance with global regulations, build stronger supplier and customer relationships, and unlock entirely new circular business models. Technology is the enabler. With SAP'sSustainabilitysolutions,  companies can move beyond fragmented initiatives to an integrated, data-driven approach that turns sustainability into a growth engine.
 
As Can Üstünberk, Executive Board Member at MarturFompak International, puts it: “We are working passionately to adapt emerging technologies to all of our business processes and to create a ‘New Digital and Sustainable’ business model—to make it more resilient, more competitive, and above all to create a more Sustainable World.”
The future of supply chains is sustainable, digital, and circular. The companies that act decisively today will be the leaders of tomorrow.
 
This blog has explored how organizations can transform their supply chains step by step, from design to reuse, and how SAP solutions can make that transformation a reality.

SAP is excited to share that its B2B trading partner platform, SAP Business Network, has received significant recognition from two leading peer review firms—TrustRadius and G2.

For the second year in a row, SAP Business Network has received a Top Rated award from TrustRadius in the Supply Chain Visibility software category. This recognition is due to the satisfaction that SAP customers have experienced with SAP Business Network, and their willingness to share their views publicly.

According to TrustRadius, the awards are based entirely on customer feedback, received, scored, and verified by the platform. TrustRadius describes the Supply Chain Visibility category as software that “tracks the production and shipment of assets between suppliers, manufacturers, retailers, distributors, and customers from a centralized platform. Supply Chain Visibility software offers tracking, analytics, and reporting on products, orders, and raw materials.”   

"SAP Business Network earning a TrustRadius Top Rated award highlights its impact in streamlining and strengthening global supply chain collaboration,” said Allyson Havener, Chief Marketing Officer at TrustRadius. “Within their reviews, customers consistently call out the platform for increasing transparency, improving partner connectivity, and driving operational efficiency.”

Through SAP’s partnership with TrustRadius, prospective customers have been able to obtain first-hand feedback from SAP Business Network customers with respect to their satisfaction with their deployments, product functionality, and business outcomes. Product reviews and ratings provide an objective viewpoint, as well as valuable product, feature, and benefit information about the SAP Business Network solution portfolio.

For example, in one review, the general manager in research and development at a large pharmaceuticals company referred to SAP Business Network as “a powerful platform that enhances collaboration and efficiency across various functions in the pharmaceutical industry.” Similarly, an engineer in a small engineering firm considers SAP Business Network to be one of the best tools to build a stronger supply chain network and “deliver on the end user promise…closing the gaps between trading partners, enabling transaction exchange, information sharing, and partner discovery.”

The SAP Business Network Market Report, developed in collaboration with TrustRadius, summarizes customer sentiment from the ratings:

  • 97% of reviewers would buy SAP Business Network again
  • 85% are satisfied with its feature set
  • 89% believe it delivers good value for the price
  • Usability Rating: 8.7/10
  • Likelihood to Recommend: 8.6/10

In addition to the recognition provided by TrustRadius, SAP Business Network has also been designated as both a Leader and a Momentum Leader by G2 in the Supply Chain Business Networks category. According to G2, products in the Leader quadrant, as defined by G2, are rated highly by G2 users and have substantial Market Presence scores. This award confirms that SAP Business Network maintains its leadership amongst our peers, as well as continues to build momentum in the marketplace, according to G2’s algorithms and comprehensive evaluation, together with verified customer reviews. Customers reviewing SAP Business Network on G2 have referred to the solution as a “game-changer,” “hassle-free,” and “a large network which can be trusted and work efficiently in the large scale.”

G2 defines the Supply Chain Business Networks category as follows:

Supply Chain Business Network software helps businesses create efficient supply chain ecosystems. These solutions offer tools to find, compare, and evaluate suitable suppliers, distributors, or manufacturers to support a company’s supply chain needs. To qualify for inclusion in the Supply Chain Business Networks category, a product must:

 - Provide a platform to search and develop supply chain business relations 
 - Connect businesses with various suppliers across the globe
 - Allow visibility to compare supplier orders and quotes
 - Provide software tools to help manage a supply chain end-to-end

The SAP Business Network team deeply appreciates the trust that our customers have placed in us. For more information about SAP Business Network visit us online. In addition, to learn more about how SAP Business Network can provide value for your organization, try our online business value calculator, developed in collaboration with IDC.*

entry.title: SAP’s New Logistics Management Module: A Cloud-Native Approach to Smarter Regional Supply Chains
entry.content:
At SAP Connect 2025 in Los Angeles, SAP unveiled a number of innovations in the supply chain space and one of the most notable is SAP Logistics Management, a new cloud-native solution designed to streamline and unify logistics operations  across warehouses, transportation, and logistics partners.

This launch reflects SAP’s strategy to simplify logistics for distributed and regional operations while enabling real-time visibility, automation, and collaboration across the supply chain network.

In this blog post, I will take you through what the module is, what its capabilities are, how it fits into the SAP ecosystem, and what it means for companies looking to modernise their logistics operations and all within one intelligent cloud platform.

Read the full blog to explore features, business impact, and practical steps to prepare your logistics operations for the next generation of SAP innovation.

What Is SAP Logistics Management?

SAP Logistics Management is a modern SaaS-based logistics solution built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
It brings together warehousing, transportation management, and partner collaboration in a single, integrated system — particularly suited for regional or satellite operations  while connecting seamlessly with SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Network.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image Source: SAP Product Information Page (sap.com)

Key Attributes

  • Cloud-native: Designed for seamless scalability, continuous innovation, and rapid deployment.
  • Unified logistics approach: Combines warehouse, transport execution, orchestration, and partner collaboration into one platform.
  • Native ERP integration: Connects easily with SAP Cloud ERP and SAP S/4HANA without heavy customisation.
  • Carrier & partner collaboration: Built-in connectivity through the SAP Business Network for real-time visibility and data sharing.
  • AI-powered operations (Joule): Leverages SAP Joule AI assistants to automate tasks, guide decisions, and reduce manual workload.

In short, SAP Logistics Management doesn’t replace heavy-duty logistics systems like SAP EWM or SAP TM, but rather extends SAP’s portfolio with a lighter, agile, intelligent logistics layer ideal for regional warehouses and distributed networks.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image Source: SAP Product Information Page (sap.com)

Positioning Within the SAP Ecosystem

SAP positions this module as a bridge for distributed logistics operations, extending logistics capabilities to smaller or regional nodes. It complements, not replaces the SAP Extended Warehouse Management and SAP Transportation Management .

Because it’s built on SAP BTP and integrates with SAP Business Network and Joule AI, the new module aligns with SAP’s vision of an intelligent, integrated supply chain.
SAP announced that general availability is expected in Q1 2026.

Benefits & Business Value

Adopting SAP Logistics Management can deliver both operational and strategic gains:

  1. Reduced operational friction: Unified logistics reduces manual handoffs and integration gaps.
  2. Faster deployment for regional nodes: Cloud-native architecture enables quicker rollouts and lower implementation costs.
  3. Improved visibility & collaboration: Real-time tracking and partner integration enhance transparency and agility.
  4. AI-driven decision support: Joule AI assists planners, automates routine actions, and reduces human error.
  5. Scalable, modular growth: Deploy gradually across logistics nodes without disrupting existing core systems.
  6. Resilient and agile operations: Respond faster to disruptions and maintain consistent service levels.
  7. Network consistency: Standardised processes and data across multiple logistics layers ensure global alignment.

Key Challenges & Considerations

While promising, success depends on thoughtful execution.
Organisations should anticipate and plan for:

  • Scope & complexity limits: The module is optimised for low-to-medium complexity; large hubs may still need EWM + TM.
  • Data integration & master data quality: Consistent, clean master data is critical for seamless performance.
  • Change management: AI-driven workflows require user adoption and training.
  • Phased rollout strategy: Identify pilot nodes and migration paths carefully.
  • Carrier & partner readiness: True collaboration depends on network adoption.
  • Monitoring & exception handling: Maintain human oversight during early automation phases.
  • Cost vs. ROI alignment: Evaluate expected efficiency gains against investment costs.

 

What Businesses Should Do Next

If your organization already runs SAP Cloud ERP or S/4HANA, this launch presents a real opportunity to modernise logistics without starting from scratch.

Recommended Next Steps

  • Map your logistics footprint: Identify which regional or satellite nodes would benefit most.
  • Start with pilot deployments: Test configurations, training, and ROI in smaller sites.
  • Ensure data readiness: Clean up and harmonize master data across materials, locations, and partners.
  • Engage carriers early: Align carriers and logistics partners with the collaboration network from the start.
  • Plan coexistence: Integrate with existing EWM/TM during the transition phase.
  • Adopt AI in stages: Roll out automation features gradually and monitor outcomes.
  • Track KPIs from day one: Measure order throughput, dock utilisation, exception rates, and on-time delivery.

Conclusion 

The introduction of SAP Logistics Management marks a pivotal step in SAP’s supply chain evolution - moving toward networked, intelligent, and modular logistics.

With its cloud-native architecture, AI-powered automation, and embedded collaboration, it offers a compelling value proposition for companies with multi-tier logistics footprints.

Ultimately, success will depend on data readiness, partner engagement, and phased adoption but for organisations ready to embrace intelligent logistics, SAP is clearly paving the way for smarter, more connected supply chains.

Thank you for reading.

entry.title: Reimagining Logistics for the Cloud Era — Inside SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
Many small and mid-sized companies still depend on siloed systems: an old WMS here, spreadsheets for transportation, and emails for carrier updates. The result? Disconnected visibility, inefficiency, and rising logistics cost.

SAP Logistics Management (LGM) reimagines this landscape.
Built natively on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), LGM unifies warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into a single intelligent cloud platform. It brings the power of SAP EWM, SAP TM, and SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) together for the first time in a cloud-native experience.

Solution Overview — Unified, Scalable, and Built for the Cloud

SAP Logistics Management bridges execution gaps by bringing every logistics function into a unified flow: from goods receipt to shipment confirmation, across multiple warehouses, modes, and carriers.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

Key Design Principles

Principle Description
Cloud-nativeSaaS architecture, auto-updates, minimal IT footprint.
Unified logistics layerIntegrates warehouse, transport, and carrier collaboration.
AI-enabledEmbedded Joule AI assistant supports planning and exception handling.
Network-readyPre-integrated with SAP Business Network for Logistics.
Composable & scalableAdopt modules progressively (start small, scale fast).

Functional Scope — From Warehouse to Network

SAP LGM delivers four main functional pillars:

  1. Warehouse Logistics (cloud EWM capabilities)

  2. Transportation Logistics (cloud TM capabilities)

  3. Network Collaboration (integrated with BN4L)

  4. Unified Planning & Control (real-time visibility cockpit)

Each pillar comes with its own set of Fiori apps, use cases, and business value.

Warehouse Logistics — Cloud EWM Simplified

Warehouse Logistics in LGM handles end-to-end inbound, internal, and outbound warehouse operations. Designed for ease of adoption, it provides structured receiving, storage, and dispatch processes with mobile execution and embedded analytics — all running in the cloud.

InternalBin management, replenishmentOptimize space and movement.
OutboundPicking, packing, staging, loadingFaster fulfillment accuracy.
MobileScanning & task confirmationReal-time execution; paperless workflow.
MonitoringDashboards & alertsImprove supervisory visibility.

Warehouse Monitor App: Imagine a retailer’s regional warehouse receiving 200 SKUs per day. The supervisor uses Warehouse Monitor to see that Putaway Zone B is overloaded while Zone C is idle. Within seconds, tasks are rebalanced to maintain service levels — no need for spreadsheets.

App Name Usage
Warehouse MonitorSupervisors track workload, resources, exceptions.
Execute Warehouse TasksOperators perform putaway/picking with handhelds.
Manage Inbound DeliveriesCreate, monitor, and post receipts for inbound deliveries.

Transportation Logistics — Intelligent Freight Orchestration

Transportation Logistics in LGM brings planning, tendering, execution, and freight costing into one intelligent workflow. It eliminates spreadsheet-based planning and manual RFQs by integrating real-time carrier collaboration.

ExecutionFreight order tracking & event managementAchieve end-to-end visibility.
CostingFreight cost calculation & invoice reconciliationImprove financial accuracy.
AppointmentDock scheduling & time windowsReduce waiting time and idle assets.

Manage Freight RFQs App: A chemical manufacturer planning an urgent dispatch to Delhi creates an RFQ in LGM. Three carriers receive tenders instantly via BN4L; within minutes, Carrier A accepts with best price and lead time — no emails or phone calls needed.

App Name Usage

Network Collaboration — Connected by Design

Network Collaboration within SAP LGM links shippers and carriers digitally via the SAP Business Network for Logistics. It replaces emails and calls with structured collaboration — carrier tenders, dock appointments, shipment events, and POD uploads all happen in one network workspace.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit
Carrier CollaborationTender acceptance / status updatesFaster onboarding, less manual follow-up.
Appointment SchedulingDock slot managementSmoother inbound/outbound flow.
Tracking & EventsMilestones & delay alertsPredictive visibility.
DocumentationProof of Delivery / Freight invoice sharingPaperless compliance.

Manage Carrier Collaboration App: A transport partner accepts a freight order from the shipper and uploads the signed POD once delivery is complete. The system automatically updates LGM and triggers freight invoice posting in ERP.

App Name Usage
Manage Carrier CollaborationDigital tender acceptance & status updates.
Schedule Dock AppointmentsDock slot coordination with carriers.
Monitor Shipment MilestonesTrack shipment events and POD status.

Unified Planning & Control — Visibility in One View

Narrative
The Unified Planning & Control cockpit serves as the command centre for logistics execution. It integrates data from warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into one consolidated dashboard, allowing real-time monitoring and decision-making.

Feature Description
Unified Planning ConsoleAggregate view of all logistics plans & statuses.
Control TowerMonitors execution progress and exceptions.
KPI DashboardsVisualises service levels and throughput.
Exception HandlingGuided workflows to resolve delays and errors.

Logistics Dashboard App: A distribution manager opens the dashboard each morning to view all facilities on one screen. If a lane’s OTD drops below 95 %, he drills into that carrier and sends an RFQ for replacement service — action taken within minutes, not days.

Key Fiori Apps in Unified Planning & Control

App Name Usage
Logistics DashboardKPI overview of logistics network.
Exception Management HubCentralised issue tracking & resolution.
Dashboard for PlanningCompare planned vs actual performance.

Integration — Seamless by Default

LGM connects to SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Network using standard APIs and content packages. Data flows bi-directionally for deliveries, goods movements, freight costs and invoices. This ensures a single source of truth across finance and operations.

Intelligence Layer — Joule AI for Smarter Decisions

Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, is built into LGM. It understands context, answers in natural language, and automates common decisions like carrier selection or route replanning.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

A planner types, “Which deliveries are at risk today?” Joule returns a list of orders facing delays and suggests rescheduling or alternate carriers based on historic performance. The planner approves in one click — no manual analysis

VisibilityUnified planning console gives end-to-end control.

entry.title: Data quality comes at a price - also in in hospitals and clinics
entry.content:
Source: generated by Google Gemini

Initial situation

Data quality plays an essential role in virtually all core processes in hospitals and clinics, whether in medication, patient care, or supply logistics. In addition, data quality is not only an operational necessity, but also vital to compliance with regulations and laws (e.g., traceability of drugs or implants).

“Garbage in = garbage out”

This makes it all the more important for every hospital or clinic to be aware of the importance of efficient data management.

In reality, however, there are many challenges in this area because the historically grown and often very heterogeneous system landscape with numerous clinical systems, ERP systems, and additional applications makes centralized and uniform data management difficult. In terms of data quality, it should be added that master data in particular must be maintained and distributed with a great deal of effort, often manually, which leads to the undesirable situation of poor-quality master data entering the clinical systems (“garbage in”) and the resulting transaction data in the form of prescriptions, services, or consumption (“garbage out”) being transferred from the systems to the ERP system.

This leads to numerous operational problems, whether in the supply logistics of medicines, medical products, and consumables for patients, suboptimal procurement of these operationally essential goods, or ultimately in rejections by health insurance companies due to incorrect service invoices.

Way out

Anyone who believes that the use of new technologies or new tools such as AI will solve the problems described above is likely to be bitterly disappointed. Instead, what is needed is the establishment of a centrally managed and organizationally strong data management system with the aim of creating a new awareness of a “data-centric” orientation within the organization.

What are the most important factors for successful data management to ensure data quality?

  1. Golden source: The principle is one “golden source” per data area or data object. Ideally, there is only one system (e.g., data warehouse, master data management) in the target architecture as the leading system or “golden source.” In practice, however, this is not always feasible due to the system landscape and its history and complexity, because the implementation does not justify the expected benefits due to the anticipated costs and implementation time. It is therefore much more important to mandatorily always define one leading system or one “golden source” per data area or data object.
  2. Validation: Data quality can be ensured most easily and efficiently at the source or during data generation. With suitable validation rules, necessary technical (e.g., pharmaceutical validation of drugs) and technical (e.g., duplicate checking) rules can be checked. This is the only way to prevent “bad” data from entering the system in the first place.
  3. Automation: Unfortunately, manual data entry or data mutations of any kind are a frequent cause of operational inefficiencies, loss of data quality, and, last but not least, great frustration for data users. The maxim is therefore: as little manual intervention as possible in data transfer or data distribution, but maximum data automation via suitable interfaces, including monitoring and, if necessary, error messages (alerting).
  4. Quality assurance: In practice, actual quality assurance is often neglected because employees are often busy with manual or semi-automated data tasks and do not have the time for quality assurance. First, the data management challenges described above must be solved so that, in the next stage of data maturity, quality assurance with corresponding quality reports or KPIs can be achieved. However, once these control mechanisms for data quality have been implemented, quality problems can be identified much earlier (e.g., data records with missing batch information for implants) and more proactively (e.g., incorrect data records in service billing), and appropriate measures can be taken. Added to this are the possibilities offered by AI to apply increasingly intelligent control mechanisms.

Source: own illustration

Conclusion

Data quality is not a “sure-fire success” and comes at a price. However, this is less about implementing new IT systems and IT tools and more about organizational awareness of the importance of professional data management. Otherwise, the old adage “garbage in = garbage out” will remain true, resulting in costly operational inefficiency and a lack of potential for more digitized and data-driven processes.

entry.title: Supply Chain Planning Reimagined: Charting the Path to Decision-Centric, Autonomous Planning
entry.content:
For decades, supply chain leaders have been on a relentless quest for greater efficiency. We've built global networks, mastered lean inventory, and embraced automation at breakneck speeds. But the last few years have upended comfortable certainties. Geopolitical upheaval, pandemic ripple effects, and climate-related disruptions have rewritten the rules—turning volatility into the new normal. Today, planning is no longer a periodic exercise; it’s a dynamic, always-on process at the heart of business resilience and agility.

To empower confident and resilient planning companies need to synchronize decision-making across end-to-end supply chains, and drive sustainable value through data science, AI-powered insights, and transformative, outcomes-centric processes.

The Challenge: Confronting Complexity and Persistent Change

Supply chain leaders face an environment defined by persistent uncertainty. Plans must change not by quarter or by month—but sometimes by hour. Yet too many organizations are still hampered by legacy silos and fragmented tools, resulting in disjointed planning, slow decision cycles, and out-of-date data. The pressure to keep peace and indeed to anticipate disruption has never been greater.

The journey from data to action is often bogged down in manual handoffs, conflicting KPIs, and limited scenario planning, limiting the impact of even the best talent and intentions.

The Vision: Decision-Centric, Autonomous Planning

The future belongs to forward-thinking leaders who embrace a new model: decision-centric, autonomous supply chain planning.

But what does this mean in practice?

  • Integrated Decision-Centric Planning to achieve resilient and optimized mid to long-range plans with an AI-powered planning platform. This enables companies to seamlessly collaborate across supply chain, commercial, and finance teams to deliver financially smart scenario plans and adapt to market shifts with confidence.
  • Autonomous Planning and Decision Making by accelerating operational agility across the business network to enhance decision-making across the entire supply chain.
  • Post Planning Decision Intelligence and Actioning to enable cross-functional planning and real-time decisions by tracking plan-to-execution against KPIs, and enabling continuous corrective actions for enhanced agility across your value chain.
  • Convergence of supply chain silos by Integrating real-time data, synchronizing production and scheduling, and collaborating across the network to enhance agility, optimize resources, and improve customer satisfaction.
  • Unified Planner Experience through streamlined planning views for supply chain leaders and decision makers.
  • Put people at the Center to enable a human-centric supply chain that transforms your operations by autonomously executing routine tasks to free up people to focus on high-value activities.

By connecting these capabilities, companies can create a unified workspace designed with planners in mind to anticipating risk, managing by exception, and relentlessly driving better outcomes.

Delivering Tangible Value: The Autonomous Advantage

What does this look like in measurable business impact?

SAP’s advanced planning platform is driving real results for companies worldwide:

  • Up to 24% improved forecast accuracy and up to 82% lower revenue loss due to stockouts by unifying data and automating demand sensing.
  • 4–20% improvement in on-time, in-full delivery, boosting customer satisfaction and loyalty.
  • Optimized working capital through smarter inventory placement and risk-aware scenario planning.
  • Faster planning cycles so that teams that once updated plans weekly can now adapt in near real-time, reallocating resources in minutes rather than days.
  • Actionable alerts and “guided” user experiences allowing supply chain teams to focus on the deviations that matter, rather than drowning in data noise.

Critically, this approach enables organizations not just to react faster, but to leap ahead, and to turn their supply chain from a cost center into a competitive differentiator.

Cultivating a Culture of Continuous Improvement

Adopting decision-centric, autonomous planning is more than a technology upgrade. It requires a fundamental shift in mindset: from reactive firefighting to proactive, empowered problem-solving.

The most successful teams are those that embrace change, foster collaboration, and encourage learning at every level.

At SAP, we strive to be a trusted partner on this journey, providing not just technology, but proven business templates, industry best practices, and a collaborative ecosystem. Our mission is to help planners and decision-makers become architects of resilience and agents of innovation in their organizations.

Charting the Path Forward

In today’s landscape, the only constant is change, and the urgency for more agile, intelligent supply chains is undeniable. The winners of tomorrow will be those who act today to unlock new levels of confidence, speed, and value creation through decision-centric, autonomous planning.

Whether you’re a seasoned supply chain executive or rising operations leader, now is the time to ask:

  • Are your planning processes set up not just for efficiency, but for resilience and continuous transformation?
  • Are your teams empowered to make decisions at the speed of business—or held back by legacy limitations?

At SAP, our promise is to help you reimagine what supply chain planning can achieve: empowering your talent, unleashing innovation, and turning complexity into your greatest advantage.
